<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Year Ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 Compared to Year Ended January&nbsp;31, 2009  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET REVENUE.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net revenue for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 increased by $35.1&nbsp;million, or 1.7%, to $2,128.5&nbsp;million, from
$2,093.4&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. Our European, retail and wholesale segments all increased revenues in the current year, while royalty revenues in our licensing
business declined. Currency translation fluctuations relating to all our foreign operations unfavorably impacted net revenue by $47.0&nbsp;million compared to the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased by $5.9&nbsp;million, or 0.6%, to $983.9&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $978.0&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The slight increase was driven by an average of 26 net additional stores during the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, resulting in a net 5.6% increase in average
square footage compared to the prior year. This growth was partially offset by a decline in comparable stores sales of 4.5%. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our Canadian retail stores
unfavorably impacted net revenue in our retail segment by $4.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=39,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=137021,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_37"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased by $3.8&nbsp;million, or 1.3%, to $300.0&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $296.2&nbsp;million for the
year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was driven by growth in our Asian business, with revenue increases in both South Korea and Greater China. The increase in Asia was partially offset by
lower North American wholesale sales. Our U.S. wholesale business continued to be impacted by the economic downturn as department stores continued to manage their inventories tightly. Our products
were sold in the U.S. in approximately 947 doors at the end of the year compared to approximately 1,057 doors at the end of the prior year. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our South
Korean and Canadian operations unfavorably impacted net revenue in our wholesale segment by $9.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased by $28.2&nbsp;million, or 3.9%, to $747.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $719.0&nbsp;million for the
year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was
driven primarily by our retail business in Europe. Wholesale revenues in Europe increased slightly, resulting from the addition of our new international jewelry business, which before
January&nbsp;2010, was operated as a licensed business. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our European operations unfavorably impacted net revenue by $29.5&nbsp;million. At
January&nbsp;30, 2010, we directly operated 84 stores in Europe compared to 61 stores at the prior year end. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalty revenue from licensing operations decreased by $2.9&nbsp;million, or 2.9%, to $97.4&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $100.3&nbsp;million
for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. This decrease was driven primarily by lower royalties resulting from lower watch product sales. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;GROSS PROFIT.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit increased by $18.9&nbsp;million, or 2.0%, to $941.5&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from
$922.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. This increase was primarily driven by our retail, wholesale and European segments as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the retail segment increased due to higher product margins resulting primarily from fewer markdowns and
less promotional activity. These improvements were partially offset by higher occupancy costs and the unfavorable translation impact of currency fluctuations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the wholesale segment increased due to higher sales in Asia and improved product margins in both our
Asian and North American wholesale businesses. These were partially offset by a decline in sales in our North American wholesale business and an unfavorable currency translation impact. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the European segment increased as a result of higher sales in our European retail business and from our
international jewelry business. These improvements were partially offset by higher occupancy costs due to our retail expansion in Europe and the unfavorable translation impact of currency
fluctuations. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin increased slightly by 10 basis points to 44.2% for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from 44.1% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was
attributable to higher product margins in our retail and wholesale segments, offset by occupancy deleverage in our European and retail segments as a result of a larger mix of European retail stores
and negative comparable store sales. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margin may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A expenses decreased by $11.1&nbsp;million, or 1.9%, to $582.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $593.8&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The decrease was driven by lower asset impairment charges related to our retail stores of
$4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $24.4&nbsp;million of impairment charges for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The decrease was also driven by lower
marketing expenses as </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=40,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1032193,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_38"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>compared
to the prior year and the favorable impact of the stronger dollar versus the prior year when translating SG&amp;A expenses for our foreign operations into U.S. dollars. The decrease was partially
offset by higher store selling expenses, due to our retail expansion in Europe, as well as higher performance-based and other compensation related costs. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
SG&amp;A rate improved by 100 basis points to 27.4% for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to 28.4% in the prior year. The net impact of the asset impairment charges in the
current and prior fiscal year accounted for all this improvement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings from operations increased by $30.0&nbsp;million, or 9.1%, to $358.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $328.8&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase in earnings from operations primarily resulted from the
following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the retail segment increased by $39.1&nbsp;million to $132.3&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $93.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase in earnings from operations was driven by higher gross profit, lower asset
impairment charges, and lower operating and marketing expenses.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment increased by $5.5&nbsp;million to $51.0&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $45.5&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase in earnings from operations was mainly driven by sales growth in Asia and lower
operating and marketing expenses in North America. This was partially offset by lower sales volume in the North American wholesale business and the unfavorable translation impact of the stronger U.S.
dollar on the South Korean business. The currency translation fluctuations, related to both our South Korean and Canadian operations, unfavorably impacted earnings from operations in our wholesale
segment by $1.2&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the European segment increased $4.6&nbsp;million to $173.2&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $168.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was due primarily to sales growth in our retail business and lower marketing
expenses, partially offset by higher store selling expenses to support the expansion of our retail business in the region. The currency translation fluctuations unfavorably impacted earnings from
operations by $5.9&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the licensing segment increased by $0.2&nbsp;million to $86.6&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $86.4&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was the result of lower marketing expenses, partially offset by lower royalty
revenues.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Unallocated corporate overhead increased by $19.4&nbsp;million to $84.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $64.9&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was primarily due to higher performance-based and other compensation related costs,
and higher professional fees, partially offset by lower brand marketing expenses. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
margin improved 120 basis points to 16.9% for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to 15.7% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, primarily as a result of the
lower SG&amp;A rate. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense decreased to $2.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to
$4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The decrease was due to a combination of lower average debt balances in Europe and lower average interest rates on the debt. Total debt
at January&nbsp;30, 2010 was $16.5&nbsp;million, and was primarily related to our capital lease in Europe. The average debt balance for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, was
$42.5&nbsp;million, versus an average debt balance of $59.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. Interest income decreased to $1.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $6.1&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, due to lower interest rates on invested cash, partially offset by higher average invested cash
balances. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=41,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=94738,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_39"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;OTHER INCOME OR EXPENSE, NET.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income, net, was $3.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to other expense, net,
of $11.3&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. Other income, net, in the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, primarily consisted of mark-to-market gains on
insurance policy investments, partially offset by net mark-to-market losses on the revaluation of foreign currency forward contracts and other foreign currency transactions.
Other expense, net, for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 primarily resulted from the decline in value of insurance policy investments and other non-operating assets. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INCOME TAXES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 was $115.6&nbsp;million, or a 31.9% effective tax rate, compared to
income tax expense of $103.8&nbsp;million, or a 32.6% effective tax rate, for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The lower tax rate in the current year was due to a higher proportion of
earnings in lower tax jurisdictions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET EARNINGS ATTRIBUTABLE TO NONCONTROLLING INTERESTS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings attributable to noncontrolling interests for the year ended January&nbsp;30,
2010 was $3.6&nbsp;million, net of taxes, as compared to $1.5&nbsp;million, net of taxes, for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was due to higher earnings from our Focus and
Mexico operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET EARNINGS ATTRIBUTABLE TO GUESS?,&nbsp;INC.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings attributable to Guess?,&nbsp;Inc. increased by $29.2&nbsp;million, or 13.7%, to
$242.8&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, from $213.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. Diluted earnings per common share increased to $2.61 per share
for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to $2.25 per share for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Year Ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 Compared to Year Ended February&nbsp;2, 2008  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET REVENUE.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net revenue for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 increased by $343.5&nbsp;million, or 19.6%, to $2,093.4&nbsp;million, from
$1,749.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. All segments contributed to this revenue growth with double-digit percentage increases. The largest contribution to this revenue
growth was generated by our European segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased by $115.6&nbsp;million, or 13.4%, to $978.0&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $862.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was driven by an average of 55 net additional stores during the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, resulting in a 12.8% increase in average square
footage compared to the prior year, and an increase in comparable store sales of 1.0% in fiscal 2009 compared to fiscal 2008. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our Canadian retail stores
unfavorably impacted revenues by $9.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased by $37.8&nbsp;million, or 14.6%, to $296.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $258.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The revenue growth was generated from our expanding Asian operations, primarily in South Korea and Greater China. During fiscal year 2009, the Company, along with
its partners, opened 20 stores and 31 concessions in Greater China and 10 stores and 29 concessions in South Korea. Our U.S. wholesale products were sold in approximately 1,057 major doors as of
January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to 1,006 major doors at the end of the prior year period. Currency translation fluctuations, relating to both our Canadian and South Korean operations, unfavorably
impacted net revenue in our wholesale segment by $16.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased by $180.6&nbsp;million, or 33.5%, to $719.0&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $538.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. All of our wholesale businesses in Europe contributed to this growth, including BARN, which we acquired in January&nbsp;2008. The growth was also attributable to
same store sales growth in our existing retail stores and the addition of new retail stores, increasing our directly operated store count to 61 stores at January&nbsp;31, 2009 from 40 stores at
February&nbsp;2, 2008. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $34.7&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our European operations. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=42,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=532532,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_40"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalty revenue from licensing operations increased by $9.6&nbsp;million, or 10.5%, to $100.3&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $90.7&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was the result of the strength of the accessories business, particularly watches, jewelry, footwear, eyewear and handbags. Licensing revenues
in fiscal 2009 did not include any royalty revenue from our BARN business which we began operating directly as part of our European operations in January&nbsp;2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;GROSS PROFIT.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit increased by $129.8&nbsp;million, or 16.4%, to $922.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from
$792.8&nbsp;million for the prior period. Most of the increase was driven by the European, retail and licensing segments as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the European operations increased due to higher sales volume in the existing European wholesale and
retail operations, higher wholesale product margins and the impact of the acquisitions of BARN in January&nbsp;2008 and Focus Spain in October&nbsp;2007.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the retail segment increased due to higher unit sales volume driven by the expansion in our store count
during the year and an increase in comparable store sales of 1.0% compared to the prior year. The increase in retail gross profit also includes the unfavorable impact of higher occupancy costs due to
the store expansion and lower product margins.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the licensing segment increased as a result of higher sales by our licensees of accessory and footwear
products. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin (gross profit as a percentage of total net revenues) decreased 120 basis points to 44.1% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from 45.3% for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008. The decline in the overall gross margin was attributable to lower product margins in our retail and wholesale segments, partially offset by higher product margins in Europe
and a higher mix of European net revenues, which generated a relatively higher gross margin than the other segments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margin may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A expenses increased by $110.2&nbsp;million, or 22.8%, to $593.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $483.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. About $46.1&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to higher store selling, merchandising and
distribution costs due to the higher sales volumes. Approximately $36.1&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to spending to support newer businesses, including BARN, Focus Spain, our G by
GUESS brand, and Greater China, as well as spending to support the continued build-out of our European headquarters in Lugano, Switzerland. In addition, approximately $24.4&nbsp;million
of asset impairment charges were recorded during fiscal year 2009 compared to $0.6&nbsp;million in the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a percentage of net revenues, SG&amp;A expense increased to 28.4% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to 27.6% for prior year period, driven by additional spending for
infrastructure and new businesses in Europe and the asset impairment charges, partially offset by expense leverage in our wholesale segment and in our corporate overhead. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings from operations increased by $19.7&nbsp;million, or 6.4%, to $328.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to earnings from operations of $309.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the retail segment were $93.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to earnings from operations of $128.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The decrease was driven by the store impairment charges of $23.3&nbsp;million and the impact
of lower product margins. This was partially offset by higher sales and the resulting gross profit due to the </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=43,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=548255,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_41"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>larger
store base, and lower advertising and marketing costs. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our Canadian retail stores unfavorably impacted earnings from operations by
$1.7&nbsp;million.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment were $45.5&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to earnings from operations of $49.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. While segment revenues increased, the decrease in earnings from operations was driven by lower
segment product margins and higher occupancy and SG&amp;A expenses to support our expanding Asian operations. Currency translation fluctuations, relating to both our Canadian and South Korean operations,
unfavorably impacted earnings from operations in our wholesale segment by $2.5&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the European segment were $168.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $120.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was primarily due to the higher sales and gross profit resulting from growth in our existing European
wholesale businesses, and our acquisition of BARN. This increase was partially offset by higher volume related operating costs and infrastructure spending, along with higher advertising and marketing
costs. Currency translation fluctuations favorably impacted earnings from operations in our European segment by $9.7&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the licensing segment were $86.4&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $77.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was the result of higher revenues generated by our product licensees. This increase was partially offset by
the loss of royalty revenue from BARN, our kids product licensee, which we acquired and now report as part of our European operations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Unallocated corporate overhead, included in SG&amp;A, was $64.9&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $68.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, mainly due to lower compensation related costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
lower gross margin and higher SG&amp;A expenses as a percentage of net revenues resulted in a decrease in operating margin of 200 basis points to 15.7% for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009 from 17.7% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense increased to $4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to
$3.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, primarily due to higher average debt balances in Europe to support working capital growth. On a comparable basis, the average debt
balance for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 was $59.2&nbsp;million versus an average debt balance of $48.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Interest income decreased
to $6.1&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, due to lower interest rates on invested cash, partially
offset by higher average invested cash balances. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;OTHER EXPENSE, NET.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense was $11.3&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, versus other expense of $1.8&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Other expense for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 primarily resulted from the decline in value of insurance policy investments and other
non-operating assets. For the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, other expense included a net charge of $0.3&nbsp;million relating to changes in foreign exchange rates on foreign
currency forward contracts and other foreign currency transactions. The forward contracts are used to hedge currency exposure primarily relating to U.S. dollar transactions in our foreign operations
in the event of a strengthening U.S. dollar. The impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar on the forward contracts during the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 resulted in a
mark-to-market gain of $18.8&nbsp;million. This gain was primarily offset by the unfavorable revaluation of U.S. dollar denominated liabilities in our foreign operations of
$18.5&nbsp;million during the same period. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=44,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=433612,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INCOME TAXES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 was $103.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a 32.6% effective tax rate,
compared to income tax expense for the prior year of $124.1&nbsp;million, or a 39.8% effective tax rate. The lower tax rate in fiscal year 2009 was due to a higher mix of profits in lower tax
jurisdictions and a decline in the Italian statutory tax rate at the end of fiscal 2008 that resulted in a devaluation of our Italian deferred tax assets at the end of fiscal year 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;NET EARNINGS ATTRIBUTABLE TO NONCONTROLLING INTERESTS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings attributable to noncontrolling interests for the year ended January&nbsp;31,
2009 was $1.5&nbsp;million, net of taxes, as compared to $0.9&nbsp;million, net of taxes, for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was primarily due to the stronger performance of
Focus and our Mexican operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET EARNINGS ATTRIBUTABLE TO GUESS?,&nbsp;INC.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings attributable to Guess?,&nbsp;Inc. increased by $27.1&nbsp;million, or 14.5%, to
$213.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $186.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Diluted earnings per common share increased to $2.25 per share
for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to $1.96 per share for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We need liquidity primarily to fund our working capital, the expansion and remodeling of our retail stores,
shop-in-shop programs, concessions, systems, infrastructure, other existing operations, international growth, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases and payment of
dividends to our stockholders. During the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company relied on trade credit, available cash, short-term borrowings from our European bank
facilities, real estate leases, and internally generated funds to finance our operations and expansion. The Company anticipates that we will be able to satisfy our ongoing cash requirements during the
next twelve months for working capital, capital expenditures, interest and principal payments on our debt, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases and dividend payments to stockholders,
primarily with cash flow from operations supplemented by borrowings, if necessary, under the Credit Facility and bank facilities in Europe, as described below under "&#151;Credit Facilities."
As of January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company had cash and cash equivalents of $502.1&nbsp;million. Excess cash and cash equivalents, which represent the majority of our outstanding cash and cash
equivalents balance, are held primarily in four diversified money market funds. The funds are all AAA rated by national credit rating agencies and are generally comprised of high-quality,
liquid investments. As of January&nbsp;30, 2010, we do not have any exposure to auction-rate security investments in these funds. Please see "ITEM&nbsp;1A Risk Factors" for a
discussion of risk factors which could reasonably be likely to result in a decrease of internally generated funds available to finance capital expenditures and working capital requirements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has presented below the cash flow performance comparison of the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, versus the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities was $358.2&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to
$228.6&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, or an improvement of $129.6&nbsp;million. The increase was primarily due to the favorable impact of working capital changes
on operating cash flows as a result of the lower growth in accounts receivable and inventory during the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to the growth in the comparable prior year period.
This was primarily driven by our European operations where we experienced a slower rate of growth relative to the prior year as a result of the global economic conditions. The increase is also
attributable to higher growth in accrued liabilities during the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to the decline of accrued liabilities in the comparable prior year period. In
addition, net earnings increased from $215.0&nbsp;million for fiscal 2009 to $246.3&nbsp;million for fiscal 2010. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=45,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=402143,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DO10101A.;8',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:53' -->
<A NAME="page_do10101_1_43"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company had working capital (including cash and cash equivalents) of $781.4&nbsp;million compared to $558.3&nbsp;million at January&nbsp;31, 2009.
The Company's primary working capital needs are for inventory and accounts receivable. Accounts receivable at January&nbsp;30, 2010 amounted to $289.6&nbsp;million, up $27.3&nbsp;million,
compared to $262.3&nbsp;million at January&nbsp;31, 2009. The accounts receivable balance at January&nbsp;30, 2010 included a positive translation impact of approximately $18.9&nbsp;million
due to currency fluctuations compared to January&nbsp;31, 2009. Approximately $133.9&nbsp;million of our receivables, or 46.2% of the $289.6&nbsp;million in accounts receivable at
January&nbsp;30, 2010, were insured for collection purposes or subject to certain bank guarantees or letters of credit. Inventory at January&nbsp;30, 2010&nbsp;amounted to $246.2&nbsp;million
compared to $239.7&nbsp;million at January&nbsp;31, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Investing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in investing activities was $90.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to
$102.2&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. Cash used in investing activities related primarily to capital expenditures incurred on new store openings and existing store
remodeling programs in the U.S. and Canada, expansion of our European retail business and infrastructure, expansion of our Asian business, improvements to headquarter buildings, investments in
information systems and other enhancements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
lower level of spending on new stores and remodeling of existing stores in the U.S. and Canada during the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 was the main driver of the lower
cash used in investing activities compared to the prior year, partially offset by improvements to our infrastructure in the current year. During the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, the
Company opened 18 new owned stores in the U.S. and Canada, 17 owned stores in Europe, 6 owned stores in Asia and 2 owned stores in Mexico, compared to 57 new owned stores in the U.S. and Canada, 20
owned stores in Europe, 10 owned stores in Asia and 4 owned stores in Mexico that were opened in the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Financing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in financing activities was $61.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, compared to
$99.1&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009. The decrease in net cash used in financing activities compared to the prior year was primarily due to higher
repurchases of shares of the Company's common stock under the 2008 Share Repurchase Program during fiscal 2009, partially offset by repayments of borrowings and higher dividends during fiscal 2010. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
interest on capital lease obligations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Does
not include insurance, taxes and common area maintenance charges. In fiscal 2010, these variable charges totaled $44.5&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Purchase
obligations represent open purchase orders for merchandise at the end of the fiscal year. These purchase orders can be impacted by various factors,
including the scheduling of market weeks, the timing of issuing orders, the timing of the shipment of orders and currency fluctuations. Accordingly, a comparison of purchase orders from period to
period is not necessarily meaningful.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
expected payments associated with the deferred compensation plan and the Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan through fiscal 2037.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Consists
of standby letters of credit for guarantee of foreign subsidiary's borrowings, workers' compensation and general liability insurance. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluded
from the above contractual obligations table is the non-current liability for unrecognized tax benefits of $14.5&nbsp;million. This liability for unrecognized tax benefits has
been excluded because the Company cannot make a reliable estimate of the period in which the liability will be settled, if ever. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Dividend Policy  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2008, the Company announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.06 per share of the Company's common
stock. Since that time, the Company has continued to pay a quarterly cash dividend, which has subsequently increased to $0.16 per common share. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
continuation of this practice, on March&nbsp;17, 2010, the Company announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.16 per share of the Company's common stock. The dividend will be payable
on April&nbsp;16, 2010 to stockholders of record at the close of business on March&nbsp;31, 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
payment of cash dividends in the future will be at the discretion of our Board of Directors and will be based on a number of business, legal and other considerations, including our
cash flow from operations, capital expenditures, debt service requirements, cash paid for income taxes, earnings, share repurchases and liquidity. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=47,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=363160,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DQ10101A.;10',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:54' -->
<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_45"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Capital Expenditures  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross capital expenditures totaled $82.3&nbsp;million, before deducting lease incentives of $5.4&nbsp;million, for the fiscal year
ended January&nbsp;30, 2010. This compares to gross capital expenditures of $90.0&nbsp;million, before deducting lease incentives of $7.5&nbsp;million, for the fiscal year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009. The Company's capital expenditures for the full fiscal year 2011 are planned at approximately $180&nbsp;million (before deducting estimated lease incentives of approximately
$10&nbsp;million), which includes key money investments for new European stores. The planned capital expenditures are primarily for retail store expansion in the U.S. and Canada, store remodeling
programs, expansion of our European retail business and infrastructure, investments in information systems, expansion of our Asian business, and other infrastructure improvements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, we periodically evaluate strategic acquisitions and alliances and pursue those that we believe will support and contribute to our overall growth initiatives. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Credit Facilities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a credit facility led by Bank of America, N.A.,
as administrative agent for the lenders (the "Credit Facility"). The Credit Facility provides for an $85&nbsp;million revolving multicurrency line of credit and is available for direct borrowings
and the issuance of letters of credit, subject to certain letters of credit sublimits. The Credit Facility is scheduled to mature on September&nbsp;30, 2011. At January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company
had $12.5&nbsp;million in outstanding standby letters of credit, no outstanding documentary letters of credit and no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Facility. See Note&nbsp;8 to the
Consolidated Financial Statements for further information regarding the terms of the Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company, through its European subsidiaries, maintains short-term borrowing agreements, primarily for working capital purposes, with various banks in Europe. Under these
agreements, which are generally secured by specific accounts receivable balances, the Company can borrow up to $228.0&nbsp;million, limited primarily by accounts receivable balances at the time of
borrowing. Based on the applicable accounts receivable balances at January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company could have borrowed up to approximately $211.7&nbsp;million under these agreements. However,
the Company's ability to borrow through foreign subsidiaries is generally limited to $185.0&nbsp;million under the terms of the Credit Facility. Under these credit agreements the Company had no
outstanding borrowings and $4.1&nbsp;million in outstanding documentary letters of credit as of January&nbsp;30, 2010. The agreements are primarily denominated in euros and provide for annual
interest rates ranging from 0.7% to 3.5%. The maturities of the short-term borrowings are generally linked to the credit terms of the underlying accounts receivable that secure the
borrowings. With the exception of one facility for $20.8&nbsp;million that has a minimum net equity requirement, there are no other financial ratio covenants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company entered into a capital lease in December&nbsp;2005 for a new building in Florence, Italy. At January&nbsp;30, 2010, the capital lease obligation was $15.8&nbsp;million.
The Company entered into a separate interest rate swap agreement designated as a non-hedging instrument that resulted in a swap fixed rate of 3.55%. This interest rate swap agreement
matures in 2016 and converts the nature of the capital lease obligation from Euribor floating rate debt to fixed rate debt. The fair value of the interest rate swap liability at January&nbsp;30,
2010 was approximately $0.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From
time-to-time the Company will obtain other short term financing in foreign countries for working capital to finance its local operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Share Repurchases  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2008, the Company's Board of Directors terminated the previously authorized 2001 share repurchase program and
authorized a new program to repurchase, from time-to-time and as market and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=48,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=845754,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DQ10101A.;10',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:54' -->
<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_46"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>business
conditions warrant, up to $200&nbsp;million of the Company's common stock (the "2008 Share Repurchase Program"). Repurchases may be made on the open market or in privately negotiated
transactions, pursuant to Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 trading plans or other available means. There is no minimum or maximum number of shares to be repurchased under the program and the program may
be discontinued at any time, without prior notice. During the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company repurchased 407,600 shares under the 2008 Share Repurchase Program at an aggregate cost of
approximately $5.3&nbsp;million, all of which occurred in the first quarter ended May&nbsp;2, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Other  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On August&nbsp;23, 2005, the Board of Directors of the Company adopted a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan ("SERP") which became
effective January&nbsp;1, 2006. The SERP provides select employees who satisfy certain eligibility requirements with certain benefits upon retirement, termination of employment, death, disability or
a change in control of the Company, in certain prescribed circumstances. The participants in the SERP are Maurice Marciano, Chairman of the Board, Paul Marciano, Chief Executive Officer and Vice
Chairman of the Board, and Carlos Alberini, President and Chief Operating Officer. As a non-qualified pension plan, no funding of the SERP is required; however, the Company expects to make
periodic payments into insurance
policies held in a rabbi trust to fund the expected obligations arising under the non-qualified SERP. The amount of future payments may vary, depending on the future years of service,
future annual compensation of the participants and investment performance of the trust. The cash surrender value of the insurance policies was $22.1&nbsp;million and $12.1&nbsp;million as of
January&nbsp;30, 2010 and January&nbsp;31, 2009, respectively and is included in other assets. As a result of an increase in value of the insurance policy investments, the Company recorded a gain
of $3.1&nbsp;million in other income during fiscal 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2002, the Company established a qualified employee stock purchase plan ("ESPP"), the terms of which allow for qualified employees (as defined) to participate in the
purchase of designated shares of the Company's common stock at a price equal to 85% of the lower of the closing price at the beginning or end of each quarterly stock purchase period. On
January&nbsp;23, 2002, the Company filed with the SEC a Registration Statement on Form&nbsp;S-8 registering 4,000,000 shares of common stock for the ESPP. During the year ended
January&nbsp;30, 2010, 73,810 shares of the Company's common stock were issued pursuant to the ESPP at an average price of $16.92 per share for a total of $1.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> INFLATION  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not believe that inflation trends in the U.S. and internationally over the last three years have had a significant
effect on net revenue or profitability. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> SEASONALITY  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's business is impacted by the general seasonal trends characteristic of the apparel and retail industries. U.S. retail
operations are generally stronger from July through December, and U.S. wholesale operations generally experience stronger performance from July through November. The European operations are largely
wholesale driven and operate with two primary selling seasons. The Spring/Summer season primarily ships from December to March and the Fall/Winter season primarily ships from June to September. The
remaining months of the year are relatively smaller shipping months in Europe. The Company's goal is to take advantage of early-season demand and potential reorders by offering a
pre-collection assortment for apparel. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> RECENTLY ISSUED ACCOUNTING GUIDANCE  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2009, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that requires an enterprise to perform an analysis to determine whether the
enterprise's variable interest or interests give it a controlling financial </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=49,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=644962,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DQ10101A.;10',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:54' -->
<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_47"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>interest
in a variable interest entity. This analysis identifies the primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity as the enterprise that has both of the following characteristics, among others:
(a)&nbsp;the power to direct the activities of a variable interest entity that most significantly impacts the entity's economic performance, and (b)&nbsp;the obligation to absorb losses or the
right to receive benefits from the entity, that could potentially be significant to the variable interest entity. Under this guidance, ongoing reassessments of whether an enterprise is the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity are required. This guidance is effective for fiscal periods beginning on or after November&nbsp;15, 2009. The Company is currently evaluating the potential
impact of the adoption of the guidance on the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2010, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that expands the required disclosures about fair value measurements. This guidance provides for new disclosures requiring
the Company to (i)&nbsp;disclose separately the amounts of significant transfers in and out of Level&nbsp;1 and Level&nbsp;2 fair value measurements and describe the reasons for the transfers
and (ii)&nbsp;present separately information about purchases, sales, issuances and settlements in the reconciliation of Level&nbsp;3 fair value measurements. This guidance also provides
clarification of existing disclosures requiring the Company to (i)&nbsp;determine each class of assets and liabilities based on the nature and risks of the investments rather than by major security
type and (ii)&nbsp;for each class of assets and liabilities, disclose the valuation techniques and inputs used to measure fair value for both Level&nbsp;2 and Level&nbsp;3 fair value
measurements. This guidance is effective for reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2009, except for the presentation of purchases, sales, issuances and settlements in the
reconciliation of Level&nbsp;3 fair value measurements, which will be effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2010. The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of
the guidance on its disclosures in the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.  </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq10101_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02650"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq10101_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM&nbsp;7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Exchange Rate Risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 46% of product sales and licensing revenue recorded for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 were denominated in U.S.
dollars. The Company's primary exchange rate risk relates to operations in Canada, Europe and South Korea. Changes in currencies affect our earnings in various ways. For further discussion on currency
related risk, please refer to our risk factors under "ITEM&nbsp;1A. Risk Factors." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Various
transactions that occur in Canada, Europe and South Korea are denominated in U.S. dollars, Swiss francs and British pounds and thus are exposed to earnings risk as a result of
exchange rate fluctuations when converted to their local functional currencies. These types of transactions include U.S. dollar denominated purchases of merchandise, U.S. dollar and British pound
denominated intercompany liabilities and certain operating expenses denominated in Swiss francs that are exposed to earnings risk as a result of exchange rate fluctuations when converted to the
functional currency. The Company enters into derivative financial instruments to manage exchange risk on certain anticipated foreign currency transactions. The Company does not hedge all transactions
denominated in foreign currency. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Forward Contracts Designated as Cash Flow Hedges  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company purchased U.S. dollar forward contracts in Europe and Canada totaling
US$87.0&nbsp;million and US$40.0&nbsp;million, respectively, to hedge forecasted intercompany royalties and merchandise purchases that were designated as cash flow hedges. As of January&nbsp;30,
2010, the Company had forward contracts outstanding for its European and Canadian operations of US$62.4&nbsp;million and US$27.7&nbsp;million, respectively, that are expected to mature over the
next 12&nbsp;months. The Company's derivative financial instruments are recorded in its consolidated balance sheet at fair value based on quoted market rates. U.S. dollar forward contracts are used
to hedge forecasted merchandise purchases over specific months. Changes in the fair value of these U.S. dollar forward contracts, designated as cash flow hedges, are recorded as a component of
accumulated other comprehensive income within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in cost of product sales in the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=50,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1043518,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DQ10101A.;10',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:54' -->
<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_48"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>period
which approximates the time the hedged merchandise inventory is sold. The Company also hedges forecasted intercompany royalties over specific months. Changes in the fair value of these U.S.
dollar forward contracts designated as cash flow hedges are recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in other income and
expense in the period in which the royalty expense is incurred. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From
time to time, Swiss franc forward contracts are used to hedge certain anticipated Swiss operating expenses over specific months. Changes in the fair value of the Swiss franc forward
contracts designated as cash flow hedges are recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in SG&amp;A in the period which approximates
the time the expenses are incurred. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of January&nbsp;30, 2010, accumulated other comprehensive income included an unrealized gain of approximately US$1.8&nbsp;million, net of tax, that will be recognized as a net
decrease to cost of product sales or other income and expense over the following 12&nbsp;months at the then current values on a pre-tax basis, which can be different than the current
year-end values. At January&nbsp;30, 2010, the net unrealized gain of the remaining open forward contracts recorded in the consolidated balance sheet was approximately
US$3.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had forward contracts outstanding for its European and Canadian operations of US$21.0&nbsp;million and US$38.5&nbsp;million, respectively, and
Swiss franc/euro forward contracts outstanding for its European operations of CHF18.0&nbsp;million. At January&nbsp;31, 2009, the unrealized net gain of these open forward contracts recorded in
current assets in the consolidated balance sheet was approximately US$8.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes net after-tax derivative activity recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (in thousands): </FONT></P>

 <P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Forward Contracts Not Designated as Cash Flow Hedges  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also has foreign currency contracts that are not designated as hedges for accounting purposes. Changes in fair value of
foreign currency contracts not qualifying as cash flow hedges are reported in net earnings as part of other income and expense. For the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company recorded a net
loss of US$10.6&nbsp;million for the Canadian dollar, euro, British pound and Swiss franc foreign currency contracts, which has been included in other income and expense. At January&nbsp;30, 2010,
the Company had Canadian dollar foreign currency contracts to purchase US$22.3&nbsp;million expected to mature over the next eight months, euro foreign currency contracts to purchase
US$117.6&nbsp;million expected to mature over the next 12&nbsp;months and euro foreign currency contracts to purchase GBP14.0&nbsp;million expected to mature over the next 11&nbsp;months. At
January&nbsp;30, 2010, the net unrealized gain of these Canadian dollar, euro and British pound forward contracts recorded on the consolidated balance sheet were approximately US$3.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had Canadian dollar foreign currency contracts to purchase US$36.5&nbsp;million, euro foreign currency contracts to purchase
US$104.0&nbsp;million and Swiss franc foreign currency contracts to purchase CHF5.3&nbsp;million. At January&nbsp;31, 2009, the net unrealized gains of these </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=51,EFW="2197641",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=218664,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAC1.10ZAC10101]DQ10101A.;10',USER='JFUSS',CD='30-MAR-2010;13:54' -->
<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_49"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Canadian
dollar, euro and Swiss franc forward contracts recorded in current assets in the Company's consolidated balance sheet were approximately US$13.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Sensitivity Analysis  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At January&nbsp;30, 2010, a sensitivity analysis of changes in the foreign currencies when measured against the U.S. dollar indicates
that, if the U.S. dollar had uniformly weakened by 10% against all of the U.S. dollar denominated foreign exchange derivatives totaling US$229.9&nbsp;million, the fair value of the instruments would
have decreased by US$25.5&nbsp;million. Conversely, if the U.S. dollar uniformly strengthened by 10% against all of the U.S. dollar denominated foreign exchange derivatives, the fair value of these
instruments would have increased by US$20.9&nbsp;million. Any resulting changes in the fair value of the hedged instruments may be more than or partially offset by changes in the fair value of
certain balance sheet positions (primarily U.S. dollar denominated liabilities in our foreign operations) impacted by the change in the foreign currency rate. The ability to reduce the exposure of
currencies on earnings depends on the magnitude of the derivatives compared to the balance sheet positions during each reporting cycle. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Rate Risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At January&nbsp;30, 2010, approximately 96% of the Company's indebtedness related to a capital lease obligation which is covered by a
separate interest rate swap agreement with a swap fixed interest rate of 3.55% that matures in 2016. Changes in the related interest rate that result in an unrealized gain or loss on the fair value of
the swap are reported in other income or expenses. The change in the unrealized fair value of the interest swap increased other expense, net by $0.5&nbsp;million during fiscal year 2010.
Substantially all of the Company's remaining indebtedness is at variable rates of interest. Accordingly, changes in interest rates would impact the Company's results of operations in future periods. A
100 basis point increase in interest rates would have increased interest expense for the year ended January&nbsp;30, 2010 by approximately $0.4&nbsp;million. This increase would be partially
offset by a favorable gain on the interest rate swap. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair value of the Company's debt instruments are based on the amount of future cash flows associated with each instrument discounted using the Company's incremental borrowing rate.
At
January&nbsp;30, 2010, the carrying value of all financial instruments was not materially different from fair value, as the interest rate on the Company's debt approximates rates currently available
to the Company.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq10101_item_8._financial_statements_and_supplementary_data."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq10101_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM&nbsp;8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information required by this Item is incorporated herein by reference to the Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary
Data listed in ITEM&nbsp;15 of Part&nbsp;IV of this report.  </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq10101_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03557"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq10101_3"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM&nbsp;9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in and Disagreements With Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq10101_item_9a._controls_and_procedures."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq10101_4"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM&nbsp;9A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Controls and Procedures.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Conclusion Regarding the Effectiveness of Disclosure Controls and Procedures  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial
officer, we conducted an evaluation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as such term is defined under Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) promulgated under the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act"). Based on this evaluation, our principal executive officer and our principal financial
officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of the end of the period covered by this annual report. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dq10101_1_50"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg10101a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Management's Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The SEC, as directed by Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, adopted rules which require the Company to include in its
Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K, an assessment by management of the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as defined in
Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f) under the Exchange Act. In addition, the Company's independent auditors must attest to and report on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over
financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f) under the
Exchange Act. The Company's internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance to the Company's management and Board of Directors regarding the preparation and fair
presentation of published financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect all misstatements. Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can
provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's management carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of the Company's principal executive officer and principal financial officer, of the
effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>
issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. Based upon this evaluation, under the framework in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated
Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, our management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January&nbsp;30, 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ernst&nbsp;&amp;
Young&nbsp;LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the Company's financial statements as of and for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;30,
2010 included in this Annual Report
on Form&nbsp;10-K has issued an attestation report on the Company's internal control over financial reporting, which is set forth below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There has been no change in our internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010 that has materially
affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
